bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard B. Russell, June 13, 1956

div1.p: Hench submits propositions to the Senate Committee on Armed Services regarding how to recognize the contributions of Lazear, Lambert, and Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Richard B. Russell, June 13, 1956
div1.opener:
June 13, 1956
Senator Richard B. Russell, Chairman
Committee on Armed Services
United States Senate
Washington, D. C.
My dear Senator Russell:
div1.p:
I have written you previously expressing my great interest in the bill,
H.R. 5590, to honor Mr. Gustaf E. Lambert. As I told you, Mr. Lambert
deserves honors but I have suggested that if Congress is willing to do
honor to Mr. Lambert after all these years, it would well for Congress
to “finish up the matter in fine and proper fashion” by honoring two ad-
ditional people: One who has never been honored before in this connec-
tion - at least not publicly - namely, Dr. Roger Post Ames who was the
physician who cared for all of the experimental cases of yellow fever of
Walter Reed and his associates, and also the memory of Dr. Jessee Lazear,
the young medical officer who, it might be said, was actually the first to
discover the cause of yellow fever but, in doing so, lost his life, leaving
his precious notes which were the basis for the subsequent successful re-
sults of Walter Reed and Doctors Carroll and Agramonte.

I enclose four propositions. I am strongly in favor of proposition 1. In
this way the full tribute would be given to those Americans who discovered
the cause of yellow fever. For reasons of which I have written, I think
proposition 1 is the most appropriate and it would maintain the distinction
which Congress has maintained up to now, with respect to those who actually
offered their bodies for the experiments, at the same time honoring Doctor
Ames and Mr. Lambert for their extremely important contribution.

Proposition 2 would be the simple addition of the names of Doctor Ames and
Mr. Lambert to the 1929 Bill and would be merely the addition of Doctor
Ames' name to the present so-called Lambert Bill, H.R. 5590. I have no
particular enthusiasm for propositions 3 and 4. They were suggested to
me when I was in Washington as acts which Congress might pass if they were
unwilling to honor Doctor Ames and Mr. Lambert (and Doctor Lazear) in the
full and proper manner.

I personally would prefer to try another year for propositions 1 and 2, if
either of these failed this year. While I favor proposition 1 over proposi-
tion 2 for reasons which I have stated previously, I will certainly not
interfere or object if Congress prefers to pass H.R. 5590, plus the addition
of the name of Doctor Ames.

When I consulted with Mr. Darden in Washington a month ago, he assured me
that the reasons for these honors were so well known by your committee
that I would not have to support that part. I am quite prepared to support
it with complete documentation which I have collected as a sort of intel-
lectual hobby since 1939. I have visited practically all the survivors
or families of survivors, and have been made the repository of extensive
data from the families of Doctors Reed, Lazear, and Agramonte, and other
survivors of the experiments.

I am prepared to appear before your committee at any time mutually agreeable
and would be glad to come at my own expense. I am off for a quick medical
trip to Europe but will return July 10 and have given Mr. Darden my addresses
if you wish to give me any instructions. I am taking the liberty of sending
this letter to the two senators from Louisiana and the representatives as I
believe that Doctor Ames, having been born in New Orleans and having been
buried there, would receive the major support from Louisiana Senators and
Congressmen.

One line about Doctor Lazear. It is probable that you never heard of his
name. Most civilians never have unfortunately, and indeed very few physicians
have; yet actually it might be said without the slightest detraction from the
wonderful work of Doctor Reed and his associates that Doctor Lazear was the
first really to discover the cause of yellow fever, carry on in Doctor Reed's
absence the three experiments, including the one on himself from which he died.
It was his notebook which gave to Doctor Reed the final data. It was entirely
necessary that Doctor Reed and the rest of the committee go ahead and, once
and for all, prove the cause of yellow fever because the world did not and
indeed could not have accepted Doctor Lazear's three experiments as conclusive
evidence. Nevertheless this was the first real break in the wall and Walter
Reed and his associates went on to finish the job in such magnificent fashion.
In summary, the great Cuban physician, Dr. Carlos Finlay, discovered the theory,
a remarkable contribution. He picked out of thousands of possibilities the right
species of mosquito but could not prove the theory. Doctor Lazear actually
proved the theory but died and Doctor Reed and his associates proved it to the
world. Since Doctor Lazear has been so neglected I do urge that Congress honor
him in this way. I would not involve Congress in controversy that would delay
honor to Mr. Lambert unduly, but I see no reason for delay as Lazear's contribu-
tion can be readily verified by the Surgeon General's Office by the reading of
General Truby's monograph. Incidentally, General Truby's conviction that Doctor
Lazear actually did inoculate himself as a secret experiment, is completely sup-
ported by information given to me by Doctor Agramonte's daughter and by several
of the volunteers, such as Moran and Kissinger. I have their actual interviews
and statements on that point.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
